title: Terrance Gore Two Time World Series Champion Dies at 34
snippets: Speedy playoff bench weapon played eight seasons in MLB
The Los Angeles Dodgers have received news that a former outfield and two-time World Series champion has died.

Former Los Angeles Dodgers outfielder Terrance Gore died at age 34, the team announced on Saturday. Gore reportedly died from complications with “what was supposed to have been a simple procedure,” according to a social media post from his wife,…
He was a part of a championship team with the Royals, who drafted him with a 20th-round selection in 2011, the Los Angeles Dodgers and the Atlanta Braves.

A member of the 2015 World Series-champion Kansas City Royals team has passed away. Speedster Terrance Gore died at age 34, the team announced on Saturday. The Macon, Ga., native enjoyed a unique MLB career, appearing in 110 regular-season games with just 74 at-bats as a pinch-running specialist. Known for his speed, Gore stole 43 bases in his career, plus five more in nine post-season appearances. He also scored 33 regular-season runs and three more in the playoffs. Gore debuted with the Royals in 2014, stealing five bases despite having just one at-bat in 11 games. He appeared for Kansas...
Gore had an unusual major-league career, appearing primarily as a pinch-runner and defensive replacement.
Terrance Gore, one of the last major leaguers to make an impact solely with breathtaking speed died Feb. 6, after complications during surgery.
titles: Terrance Gore dies at 34: Three-time World Series champion played for Royals, Cubs, Dodgers and Mets

Gore was known for his speed and played eight MLB seasons, primarily as a pinch-runner and defensive replacement, winning titles with the Kansas City Royals, Los Angeles Dodgers, and Atlanta Braves.
